newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish ministry makes bank consolidation move.
newsitem.headline: Polish ministry makes bank consolidation move.

text.p: The Polish Finance Ministry moved its stakes in three banks to state-owned Bank Polska Kasa Opieki SA (Pekao SA) making an important step in its banking consolidation plan, a senior ministry official said.

As the result of the move, the share capital of Pekao SA will be raised by 97.65 million zlotys from earlier 40 million, issuing 244,125 shares, paid for by the treasury with shares of Pomorski Bank Kredytowy (PBKS), Bank Depozytowo- Kredytowy (BDK) and Powszechny Bank Gospodarczy (PBG).

"The share capital of Pekao SA was increased by placing the state treasury's shares in its dependent banks PBKS, BDK and PBG in Pekao SA, so now Pekao SA acts as the owner of the banks," Wieslaw Federowicz told a news conference.
He said the move had yet to win the approval of the central bank and a clearance from the government's anti-monopoly body, and expected the group to become a legal fact by the end of this month.@
He said a decision on how the group would be privatised was expected late next year as the banks needed time to consolidate their balance sheets and adjust management to the new structure.
"The final decision on Pekao's privatisation method would be taken in autumn next year, as it takes time to improve management of the whole group and consolidate its accounting," Federowicz said.
He said a government banking privatisation programme aimed to privatise the Pekao group by 2000 and that the deadline would be met. @

The group, which jointly has about 20 percent of Poland's banking services market, had a combined balance sheet total of 37 billion zlotys in mid-1996 and own assets of nearly two billion zlotys, topping all other Polish banks.
